title: The US properties in Australian investors' sights
text:
Demographic trends have created a tailwind for the build-to-rent sector in the past 10 years with Millennials, the largest cohort of tenants in the sector, renting at a higher rate than ever and that trajectory is expected to continue.

"[MIllennials] are putting off major life decisions, such as getting married and having children, and, more importantly, they have been saddled with unprecedented student debt," Ms Rao said.

Nick Evans, Nuveen Real Estate's head of Australia, said it would be unusual for a domestic super fund not to have exposure to build-to-rent property in the US given it offered investors geographical exposure and low volatility.

Last year Australia's largest super fund, AustralianSuper, encouraged by the long-term growth prospects of the sector, entered the US build-to-rent market with the acquisition of a 239-apartment complex in Florida for US$54.7 million.

Around the same time, First State Super's enthusiasm towards the sector was underscored by the launch, in partnership with property giant Lendlease, of a $US1 billion platform to fund BTR developments across the US.

QSuper recently acquired Trellis House, a build-to-rent development in Washington DC.

Australia's second-largest super fund, QSuper, also recently made its first foray into the US sector with the acquisition of a new apartment development called Trellis House, in Washington DC.

Advertisement

It's part of a broader geographical diversification play for QSuper, with the fund having increased its real estate investments in the US from 15 per cent at the beginning of 2018 to 31 per cent of its $4.8 billion global property portfolio.

QSuper's head of funds management Elizabeth Kumaru.

Elizabeth Kumaru, head of funds management for QSuper, said the Queensland-based super fund would look to increase its exposure to the build-to-rent sector given its resilience during "down economic environments" when listed equity markets, which super funds tend to have a large exposure to, are performing relatively poorly.

"Historically, we've had a real estate portfolio being dominated by retail and office. Office tends to be more cyclical in a downturn and that's because tenants tend to be businesses and so in a struggling economy, they cut back staff and they don't need as much office space," Mrs Kumaru said.

"In multifamily what you tend to find is that it is more defensive in down markets and that's because people need somewhere to live, so if you're in a good location, particularly in the city, it creates a closer, cheaper option and the income can tend to be more stable in down markets."

Mrs Kumaru added that while QSuper would like to increase its exposure to BTR, every decision was assessed on a risk-adjusted return basis.

"Historically, we've found it challenging to buy these assets at an appropriate risk-adjusted returns relative to the other investments that we had been shown."
description: Eagerness among institutional investors to focus on defensive property assets in an uncertain economic environment is pushing Australian capital into build-to-rent projects in the US.
